title: Riot support is a bunch of spambots
body:
Edit:
I just received a 5th response which was the EXACT SAME MESSAGE word-for-word as the second response I received. So I am 100% confident in my allegation that no real person is working those support tickets. Use my experience as a warning.. you're not being listened to.

As Jubbinaut said in his reply down there, though, the system supposedly detected something wrong. I understand typing "I agree" was just a warning, which is why I typed it instead of refusing to. But I in no way left that match even for a minute, I didn't troll or do anything that was not towards the aim of winning the match. The only time I was sitting around idle was when my champion was dead and i was waiting for them to respawn. Like always, it seems Riot is releasing product before applying enough to tests to render it functional (every new champion is an example of that).


==================

I'm either being trolled by the support staff for having a bad attitude (it was a test to see if they'd acknowledge the attitude), or sending in a ticket is only mass answered by a server of bots and pre-written messages and pre-written reply messages.

LeaverBuster made me type "I agree" for leaving/being disconnected from a match. However, the last time I disconnected from a match was in September, probably August, when League was having DDoS and other server problems. I doubt they're issuing punishments from that long ago. So I sent in a support ticket, not to get anything changed, but to get information on and let the support staff know that "Hey, Leaver Buster is flagging me for no reason. Look at my account and tell me if I'm wrong, or acknowledge LeaverBuster made a mistake and you'll aim to fix the system."

After this experience I'm concerned as to why Riot even has a support system.

replies.body:
Hey DeadlyQuestion,

I appreciate that you bubbled this up so that I could take a look.  As the Leaverbuster Revamp is still a bit new we've been cautious about the level of information that is shared to prevent players from abusing the system.  I think this approach may be a bit too conservative and I will talk to the specialists to see what additional information they can share to help address the issue.

After looking at your situation, I believe I think I've found the point of confusion.

The system audited you on December 12th, 2014 in a Normal Summoner's Rift game where you played as Quinn.

You can see the stats of the game on our website here:
http://matchhistory.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/#match-details/NA1/1665691057/49890579


I was able to verify that you did actively stop participating after the 12 minute mark, and that the leaver penalty applied to your account was justified.

However, I agree that we should work on the messaging and information provided to you and other affected players in the future.  I will work with the team to see what we can do on that front.

I really see that on these boards that people don't think Riot listens to them at all, and yet for the past two years they have fixed literally everything I can think of that needed fixing that the community has asked for. 

I appreciate everything what you guys working at Riot do. You have literally the biggest demand for change in any game I've seen and played, and you guys handle it to the best of your ability. I know the job here gets tough. Keep at it! There's a reason the game has lasted as long as it has.

EAST
COAST
SERVERS

Hi CookieWookie,

Hey LumpForrest!

Sorry, I didn't mean to avoid any questions!  We don't use any bots or automation to answer our support tickets.  We do have some rather big challenges given the size of the player base and the type of questions that players ask us.   For those reasons we have some specialists that have more generalized training in a number of issues.  Their answers will usually not be as deep or complex.  And to be honest with you, for the majority of the tickets that come in this is more than sufficient.

The trick for us, as an organization, is training which helps Generalists identify when an issue requires a more in depth answer and how to escalate that issue to the right people.  When I look at the interaction that DeadlyQuestion had, what I take away is that we need better guidance on these escalations.  That way, in an alternate world, DeadlyQuestion gets the answers he needs in a more timely manner.

For me, this brings it back to my original point, which is we're still trying to figure out the limits to the information we're looking to share about Leaverbuster to prevent any abuse of the system.  I think we may be able to give Generalists more information that they can share with players to stop this from happening in the future.

you dont use bots, but you do use scripted responses. I just sent in a ticket recently regarding a chat restriction I had received. In the message I state that I know why I received the restriction and that I deserve it but then go on to say that there needs to be more clarity when the restriction gets applied. You can read the ticket yourself to see what I said in detail. What irritates me is that the second response to my ticket was the exact same as the first response. It just said that they wouldn't lift the restriction...

I never once asked for it to be removed... Both support specialists apparently skimmed my ticket, saw chat restriction and assumed i wanted it removed. If that is what all of your support specialists do then they all missed something during training. It is pretty important to read a ticket in its entirety in order to give a proper response. It is disappointing to find out that your player support personnel do not.

I have sent in many tickets but this is the first one that I must say I am not satisfied with.

Paul is a hard working riot ticket responder.  Paul has crafted his skill to manage 2400 responses in a single workday.  In his endeavors, Paul will read many tickets simply telling riot to fix their shit and that they are greedy for money and don't spend any of it on servers.  Other tickets will have incredibly broken english and Paul must piece together misspelled words and improper versions of there/they're to comprehend what the person is even asking let alone how to respond to it.  He's learned to skim most messages to find the bulk of what they're asking and then respond accordingly.  Having to fully read all those broken responses and flame-tickets would hinder his abilities and make him fall behind his response quota.  You are his 1100th ticket of the day.  Nobody cannot assess where your ticket falls in this grand scheme of qualification, so he does the standard procedure.  "chat restriction, chat restricted, shouldn't have, chat restriction" Well he obviously isn't happy with his chat restriction, but due to the evidence I can't lift it for him.  As this is the 73rd person of the same issue, i have a pre-copied response in order.  Surely this 1 out of 73 people isn't the only one on the topic of chat restrictions that isn't asking it to be removed.  

You are not satisfied with Paul?

Nope, I am not satisfied in the slightest. I have had a support job myself, is it grating having to read through tickets with poor grammar and/or broken english on something I could do nothing about, yes it is. Did I still read every single word in the ticket in order to make sure the response I was giving was the correct one, you are damn right I did. That was what I was hired to do and what was expected of me. If I had sent a response that did not even address what the ticket was sent in for and received a complaint because of that response, I would have either been sent back to training or canned on the spot depending on the situation. If you cannot do your job in its entirety, whether it be on a good day or bad, you need to find a new line of work. If you think what you just described is okay and follow the same work ethic, do not expect to hold your job for very long because if you said to any boss "1 out of 73 isn't that big a deal" you would be fired on the spot.

In this image, Mr. Mousepad gives the exact same response that Excellion gives me two posts above (check out screen shots 02 and 03 in the original post of this thread). So it is more than just a representative giving general responses, if they are actually people behind this message, then they're copying and pasting from a list of responses. I would call these copy/paste responses as a form of automation even if not full fledged scripts or bots.

But in your(/Riots) defense, like you explain, this might be necessary given the sheer volume of tickets that are submitted. I agree that general copy/paste responses are acceptable if after the generic messages aren't resolving the issue, the situation is identified and given closer attention, and I appreciate you acknowledging this should have happened and didn't (instead of denying the whole thing/somehow placing blame on myself).

Since you seem displeased with the support responses, allow me to pass along some information I've gleaned from here on the boards.

1. The "I agree" message is not representative of any form of sanction placed on your account. It's a one-time notice issued the *first* time the updated Leaverbuster system takes note of you.
2. Judging from the posts about it, the game it detected was the one *immediately* prior to your receiving the pop-up.
3. No information has been given about changes to the detection algorithms, leading me to believe that they haven't been significantly adjusted from those used for the old Leaverbuster, which implies:
4. Whatever it detected you doing (or more accurately, not doing) in this instance, it would also have detected in the prior iteration of the system as well. You simply wouldn't have known about it.

All of that said, while I absolutely believe that you were *connected* throughout that game, I'm also forced to admit that the very fact of its detection implies something off. The detection algorithms used for LB are pretty clever, and very capable of recognizing idling, afk farming, and other, less obvious forms of being afk.

The *way* that they do this hasn't been fully established, but I've heard (and seen evidence) that experience gain is part of the equation, and I suspect that enemy interaction may be involved as well.

I wouldn't worry about it *too* much, at least not yet, but I would try to remain aware of how I play, and how active I was being.

Of course, your mileage may vary, and none of this may be particularly meaningful at all. If that's the case, feel free to ignore it.
